thread.section_title: Latest business and finance news from New Zealand and the world's key markets - Yahoo New Zealand Finance
thread.title: Retail data sends $A to two month low
thread.title_full: Retail data sends $A to two month low

title: Retail data sends $A to two month low
text:
Fri, Jul 3, 2015, 7:57 PM NZST - New Zealand Markets closed Retail data sends $A to two month low AAP – 10 minutes ago Print 
The Australian dollar hit a two and a half month low after sluggish local retail spending figures disappointed the market. 
At 1700 AEST on Friday, the local unit was trading at 75.84 US cents, down from 76.34 cents on Thursday. 
It fell as low as 75.67 US cents in earlier trade, its weakest level since April 14. 
Official data showed retail spending rose 0.3 per cent in May, which was short of economists' expectations of a rise of 0.5 per cent. 
RBC foreign exchange strategist Keng Goh said the Aussie dollar's fall after the release of the retail figures was the day's big move. 
"The soft print is surprising given a number of supportive factors in May, including a 25 basis point rate cut," he said. 
"Otherwise, foreign exchange markets have been very quiet." 
At 1700 AEST, the Australian dollar was at 93.35 Japanese yen, down from Thursday's close of 94.21 yen, and at 68.35 euro cents, down from 68.94 euro cents. 
Trading volumes in currency markets were low as the US observes its Independence Day public holiday, and as traders play it safe ahead of a Greek referendum on financial reforms needed to secure new bailout funds. 
"In Greece, polling by Ethnos showed the referendum outcome is still finely balanced," Mr Goh said. 
"Meanwhile, Prime Minister Tsipras made a surprising statement claiming if the no vote wins he guarantees he will be in Brussels the next day and will sign a deal - just adding to the confusion of most heading into the referendum weekend." 
Meanwhile, the bond market was firmer. 
FIIG Securities director of fixed income sales Simon Michell said there's been a move to safer assets, like bonds, ahead of the vote. 
"They're certainly uncertain, there's no expected outcome," he said. 
"If you look at the polls there's not real view emerging that markets are happy to run with, so they're battening down the hatches in anticipation of either a yes or a no result." 
At 1630 AEST, the September 2015 10-year bond futures contract was trading at 96.885 (implying a yield of 3.115 per cent), up from 96.845 (3.155 per cent) on Thursday. 
The September 2015 three-year bond futures contract was at 97.920 (2.080 per cent), up from 97.870 (2.130 per cent). @YahooNZBusiness on Twitter, become a fan on Facebook More rate cuts this year unlikely - survey AAP
